attributes.title: Choice 7575-558-86
attributes.description: In a previous study, we found that when participants were asked to focus on the choices that had when making a judgment, they are less susceptible to the anchoring bias. The goal of the current study is to test whether this effect is reduced in a divided attention condition.

attributes.title: Choice 7575-559-57-2
attributes.description: Our primary hypothesis is that participants surrounded by a group of friends that strongly believe in choice (i.e., friends who believe people always have a choice) will be less likely to agree with xenophobic ideas compared to participants surrounded by a group of friends that do not strongly believe in choice (i.e., friends who believe people are limited by circumstances).

attributes.title: Hidradenitis suppurativa and major adverse cardiac events: A systematic review and meta-anlaysis
attributes.description:
1. * Review title.

Hidradenitis Suppurativa and Major Adverse Cardiac Events: A Systematic Review and Mwta-Analysis.

2. * Anticipated or actual start date.

04/03/2020

3. * Anticipated completion date.

01/05/2020

4. * Stage of review at time of this submission.

Preliminary searches - completed
Piloting of the study selection process - completed		
Formal screening of search results against eligibility criteria - completed		
Data extraction - not started	
Risk of bias (quality) assessment - not started		
Data analysis - not started			

5. * Named contact.

Adrian Bailey

6. * Named contact email.

abail082@uottawa.ca

7. * Organisational affiliation of the review.

University of Ottawa

8. * Funding sources/sponsors.

None

9. * Conflicts of interest.

None

10. * Review question.

Is Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS) associated with an increased rate of Major Adverse Cardiac Events compared to the general population?

P: Adult (>18 years) patients with HS
I: None
C: General adult population (>18 years)
O: Major Adverse Cardiac Events (myocardial infarction, cerebrovascular accident, cardiovascular associated death)
S: cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional studies

11. * Searches.

On April 16th, 2020, MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and Embase databases were searched from their inception using keywords “hidradenitis”, “cerebrovascular”, “cardiovascular”, and “infarction”, without restrictions.

12. * Condition or domain being studied.

Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is an inflammatory disease of the skin and has been associated with various cardiac risk factors. However, there is conflicting evidence as to whether HS is associated with Major Adverse Cardiac Events, such as cerebrovascular accident, myocardial infarction, and cardiovascular-associated death.

13. * Participants/population.

Adult patients with HS (>18 years of age)

14. * Intervention(s), exposure(s).

None

15. * Comparator(s)/control.

General adult population (>18 years)

16. * Types of study to be included.

Case-control, cohort, and cross-sectional studies. Other study types and grey literature are excluded.

17. * Main outcome(s).

Major Adverse Cardiac Events (MACEs), such as cerebrovascular accident (CVA), myocardial infarction (MI), and cardiovascular-associated death.

* Measures of effect

Risk estimates: Incidence rate ratio, Hazard ratio, and Odds ratio.

18. * Data extraction (selection and coding).

Two independent reviewers (AB and HL) will extract the study characteristics and results in duplicate. Extracted study characteristics will include information on the authors, publication date, country, study design, data sampling dates, ethnicity of population, number of participants, and adjusted factors in the analysis. The extracted results will include risk estimates, such as Odds ratio, Hazard ratio, incidence rate ratio, and their 95% confidence intervals. Authors will be contacted for data, if required.

19. * Risk of bias (quality) assessment.

The risk of bias for each study will be determined using the Newcastle-Ottawa scale.

20. * Strategy for data synthesis.

Review Manager Software, version 5.3 (Nordic Cochrane Centre, Cochrane Collaboration) will be used to conduct the meta-analysis when three or more studies provide useable data for an outcome. The meta-analysis will be conducted using the Der Simonian–Laird random-effects model, to account for heterogeneity between studies, and effect estimates will be combined using generic inverse variance method. Risk ratios (RR), incidence rate ratios, or hazard ratios will be pooled as they will be considered relative measures of risk for cohort studies. Risk estimates will be reported through odds ratios (OR) for case-control studies. Case-control studies and cohort studies will be analyzed separately given differences in study design. Risk estimates will be combined to estimate the risk of MACEs in both the cohort and case-control studies. The pooled analysis of less than three studies will be presented only for qualitative interpretation. Heterogeneity will be assessed using the I² statistic, and an I² greater than 50% will be considered substantial heterogeneity. Funnel plots will be used to assess for publication bias. P<0.05 will be considered significant.

21. * Analysis of subgroups or subsets.

Subgroup analysis will be performed for MI, CVA, and cardiovascular-associated death.

22. Language.

English

23. * Country.

Canada

24. Other registration details.

Also submitted for registration on PROSPERO.

25. Dissemination plans.

Publication to a major dermatology journal.

summary.value: Although hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) has been associated with various cardiac risk factors, there is conflicting evidence as to whether HS is associated with Major Adverse Cardiac Events (MACEs), such as cerebrovascular accident (CVA), myocardial infarction (MI), and cardiovascular-associated death. For example, one recent, large study in the United States found HS was associated with 64% reduced odds of having myocardial infarction while another recent, large study in the United States found HS was associated with 21% increased incident rate of myocardial infarction.  Similar contradictions exist with regards to CVA, as some studies find an increased incidence, some find no difference incidence or odds, while another finds a decreased odds of CVA in HS populations. Lastly, these associations have not been tested across a variety of populations and ethnicities. Here, we aim to resolve these discrepancies through a systematic review and meta-analysis of the literature.

registration_responses.summary: Although hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) has been associated with various cardiac risk factors, there is conflicting evidence as to whether HS is associated with Major Adverse Cardiac Events (MACEs), such as cerebrovascular accident (CVA), myocardial infarction (MI), and cardiovascular-associated death. For example, one recent, large study in the United States found HS was associated with 64% reduced odds of having myocardial infarction while another recent, large study in the United States found HS was associated with 21% increased incident rate of myocardial infarction.  Similar contradictions exist with regards to CVA, as some studies find an increased incidence, some find no difference incidence or odds, while another finds a decreased odds of CVA in HS populations. Lastly, these associations have not been tested across a variety of populations and ethnicities. Here, we aim to resolve these discrepancies through a systematic review and meta-analysis of the literature.

attributes.title: Comm 4800
attributes.description: Main Research Question: Does teaching parents about the potential negative impacts of sharing information about their children on social media through a video format lead to a short-term attitude change in how they feel about sharing inappropriate information about children on social media?

q1.value: Gillian Elizabeth Grose, Sterling Williams-Ceci, Annika Pinch

q2.value:
H1a: Compared to people in the control condition, people in the experimental conditions will be less likely to decide to post inappropriate potential posts and give lower appropriateness ratings to inappropriate posts after watching the intervention video. 

H1b: Compared to those in the experimental condition with just the intervention video, people in the experimental condition with the intervention video plus the summarization writing task will be less likely to post inappropriate potential posts and give lower appropriateness ratings to inappropriate posts after watching their intervention video and doing the summarization writing task. 

H2: People in all three conditions will not differ significantly in their likelihood to post appropriate potential posts and will give the same appropriateness rating to appropriate posts after watching their assigned video. 

H3: Compared to those in the control condition, people in the experimental conditions will place greater importance on asking their child’s permission to post about them on social media after watching the intervention video.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We have 3 Conditions that the participants could be assigned to:

Experimental Condition 1: In this condition, participants will be shown a video made up of clips from the Atlantic which cautions parents about what they post online. 

Experimental Condition 2: In this condition, participants will be shown that same video made up of clips from the Atlantic which cautions parents about what they post online but they will additionally be asked to summarize what they have taken away from this video after watching it. 

Control Condition: In this condition, participants will be shown a control video about parents trying to deal with their kids being picky-eaters, which has nothing to do with our topic of interest.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We intend to sample about 250 parents from Amazon's Mechanical Turk Prime. Each participant will receive $1.80 for completing our study. 

We will exclude participants who at the end indicate their data should not be used because either the video did not load successfully or they believe they did not devote their attention to the study.
We plan on excluding any participants who in the survey indicated they are not a parent. Prior to committing to the study participants will be asked to participate in the study only if they have a child under the age of 18.

q11.value: We intend to sample 250 parents. Participants will be divided evenly between conditions, with approximately 83 in each one. This is an approximation and may change due to budget constraints.

question.value: We will manipulate the type of intervention people receive, as described in the Design Plan section. The two potential types of interventions are videos concerning the dangers of "sharenting." One intervention simply consists of watching this video, while the second consists of watching it and then writing a reflection. The control condition receives a video about children who are picky eaters, intended to be an unrelated video. We also manipulate the type of photos and posts we ask parents about: this is a within-subjects factor, as everyone has to answer questions about appropriate and inappropriate photos and posts.

The dependent variable is parents' attitudes towards posting information about children. This is measured by asking questions evaluating pictures and posts on whether they would post it or not, questions about what they think is appropriate to post, and a question about their own attitude about the importance of asking their children’s permission to post about/of them. All these measurements are taken pre and post-intervention.

For questions evaluating pictures and posts on whether they would post it or not (“Potential Posts”):
Apriori to the study, 4 pictures, and 4 written posts were selected as appropriate to post online, and 4 pictures and 4 posts were selected as inappropriate. These ratings were based on a study that revealed children’s discomfort levels with various types of photos and posts parents often put about them online (Moser et. al, 2017). These photos and posts were identified as appropriate or inappropriate by researchers, but not identified in this way to participants. We will show each photo and post to participants (meaning they see 8 pictures and 8 posts in the pre-test and 8 pictures and 8 posts in the post-test) and ask whether they would post them about their child(ren) on social media. We will compute sum scores for appropriate and inappropriate categories by taking the numbers of total items (photos and posts) that people say they would post. This would give us average scores for people’s propensity to post child-related items in the pre and post-tests, separately. 

For questions about what they think is appropriate to post (“Appropriateness Ratings”):
Apriori to the study, 4 appropriate situations, and 8 inappropriate situations were identified by researchers but not identified to participants. These ratings were based on a study that revealed children’s discomfort levels with various types of photos and posts parents often put about them online (Moser et. al, 2017). For each situation, participants will answer a 7 point Likert scale ranging from “Absolutely Inappropriate” to “Absolutely Appropriate”. We will then re-code the Likert Scale values as numbers between 1 and 7 (“Absolutely Inappropriate” to “Absolutely Appropriate”) and average the numbers to make an average score per condition (Appropriate and Inappropriate) in both the pre and the post-test. 

For the question about assessing their own attitude towards the importance of asking their children’s permission to post about/of them (“Permission Asking”):
Participants are asked how important it is to ask their child’s permission before posting about them on a 7 point Likert scale ranging from “Not At All Important” to “Extremely Important”. We will re-code this Likert Scale values as numbers between 1 and 7 (“Not At All Important” to “Extremely Important”) and compare this number across the pre and post-test for each condition.
Likert scale ratings of behaviors for the Appropriateness Ratings measure will averaged per type of photo in the pre and post test phases of each condition.

To test Hypotheses 1a and 1b, we will use two 2-way ANOVA models. The first model will focus on the implicit attitudes data we collect about whether people would post inappropriate posts or photos (Potential Posts).  We will use R studio for generating the model. After reading in a .csv file with our data and re-coding it accordingly, we will run an ANOVA with the following formula: 

aov(potential_posts_inapp ~ conditions_combined + potential_posts_inapp_diff)

This ANOVA will compute whether how likely people are to post inappropriate items differs significantly based on the condition and their baseline attitudes toward posting inappropriate media before the intervention. If the difference between the pre and post test term (potential_posts_inapp_diff) is significant in the model, it would indicate that attitudes significantly shifted after the intervention in at least one of the three conditions. Additionally, if the conditions_combined term (conditions_combined) is statistically significant, this will indicate that people’s likelihood of posting the items depends on the intervention being tested. We can then perform pairwise comparisons between these three measures of interest (using the TukeyHSD function) to reveal which condition(s) showed differences in people’s likelihood of posting inappropriate items, and whether these effects differed significantly from those people’s baseline opinions. 

If we then find that the experimental conditions both differed significantly from the control condition, it would support Hypothesis 1a. Further, if we find that the outcome of the Intervention with Writing condition (Experimental Condition 2) differed significantly from the outcome of the non-writing intervention (Experimental Condition 1), it would support Hypothesis 1b. Including the pre-test attitude measure for each condition as a covariate in the model allows us to see whether the resulting attitudes in each condition were changed as a result of the intervention given. We will use an identical model to test for differences in the explicit attitudes toward posting inappropriate types of content online, replacing the outcome variable with a term for the Appropriateness Ratings of inappropriate situations.

To test Hypothesis 2, we will follow the same procedure for creating a two-way ANOVA model as described above, but we will test differences in the responses to the appropriate photos and posts instead of the inappropriate ones. We will use the term potential_posts_app to signify the attitudes toward posting appropriate items during the post-test in each condition. We will also use the term potential_posts_app_diff to represent the changes in attitudes from before the intervention. The same reasoning in the first model will apply here. 

If the outcome term is insignificant in this model, it would indicate support for Hypothesis 2, because it would mean that attitudes toward posting appropriate items would not differ among the conditions. If the term is significant, it indicates that either our intervention affected attitudes toward posting appropriate media, or that baseline attitudes toward posting it were already significantly different among the conditions. We can solve this question by looking at the difference in attitudes term: if it is significant, the attitudes of the groups already differed before our intervention, meaning our intervention still did not affect these attitudes, supporting Hypothesis 2. If this term were insignificant, it would imply that our intervention impacted these attitudes, a topic for discussion in our paper since this is not necessarily desirable. We will use an identical model to test for differences in the explicit attitudes toward posting appropriate types of content online, replacing the outcome variable with a term for the Appropriateness Ratings of appropriate situations.

Finally, we can use a similar model to test Hypothesis 3. We can include a term for the Permission Asking variable (permission_asking) as our outcome variable, and include the conditions_combined term along with a permission asking_diff term as we did for the differences in pre and post test outcomes for the other attitude measures. The same reasoning used in the first model applies: if the conditions_combined term is significant, then the permission asking attitudes differ significantly depending on whether people got the intervention or not. If the difference term is significant, it means that the attitudes changed as a result of the intervention in at least one of the conditions. We can then use the Tukey pairwise comparisons method to investigate exactly which conditions cause this effect.

q18.value:
We will recode the yes/no answers to whether people would post the photos and posts as 1=yes and 0=no. This will allow us to sum these counts for each person across the items. 

We will recode the Likert scale options as numbers from 1-7, corresponding to the number of the choice

q22.value: We will include questions for exploratory purposes concerning social media usage, parents posting behaviors when posting of/about their children. We also include basic demographic measures, which will be used in correlational analyses with the dependent measures. Any findings from this phase of the data analysis will be exploratory in nature.

H2: People in all three conditions will not differ significantly in their likelihood to post appropriate potential posts and will give the same appropriateness rating to appropriate posts after watching their assigned video. 

H3: Compared to those in the control condition, people in the experimental conditions will place greater importance on asking their child’s permission to post about them on social media after watching the intervention video.

q1.value: There is abundant health-related misinformation in internet and misinformation is generally more popular than verified information. While most existing studies focused on political and social issues, health-related misinformation is also highly prevalent on social media. Our research will focus on health-related fake news on social media. We assume that conspiracist ideation positively, analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking negatively, associated with belief in fake news about health.

q3.value: There is abundant health-related misinformation in internet and misinformation is generally more popular than verified information. While most existing studies focused on political and social issues, health-related misinformation is also highly prevalent on social media. Our research will focus on health-related fake news on social media. We assume that conspiracist ideation positively, analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking negatively, associated with belief in fake news about health.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Belief in health-related fake news on social media is associated with: (a) a higher conspiracist ideation; (b) less actively open-minded thinking; (c) less analytic thinking.
Hypothesis 2: Analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking simultaneously mediate the association between conspiracist ideation and belief in health-related fake news.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: All participants will complete GCB scale, CRT scale, AOT scale, and complete the 12-item news accuracy judgment task. As CRT requires relatively high working memory resources (Evans & Stanovich, 2013). After each news headline stimulus, participants will be presented with the accuracy judgement question and the sharing intention question. Last part of the survey will be demographic questions including age, gender, education and proficiency in English.

q9.value: participants will be assigned with tests in random order, which will be counterbalanced across participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit participants via Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Target group is Mturk workers with good response quality (e.g. an acceptance rate over 95%) who are over 18 and live in the U.S..

q14.value: Since the preexisting studies showed a small to medium effect size, we calculated an appropriate sample size using G*Power to expect an effect size of 0.20.

question.value:
Conspiracist ideation is measured by 15-item Generic conspiracist beliefs (GCB) scale which is psychometrically verified and conceptually consistent with the monological construct of conspiracist ideation (Brotherton, French, & Pickering, 2013). Participants are instructed to rate to what extent they think the statements to be true on a 5-point Likert scale (1=definitely not true; 2 = probably not true; 3 = not sure/cannot decide; 4 = probably true; 5 = definitely true). 
Analytical thinking is measured by a reworded version of Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) combining three items from Frederick (2005) and four non-numeric CRT from Thomson and Oppenheimer (2016). The 7-item test was introduced by Pennycook and Rand (2018) with an acceptable reliability proved, Cronbach’s α = 0.77. Participants’ score on CRT is the number of correct responses. Higher scores indicate better cognitive ability and/or more analytic cognitive style (compared to intuitive cognitive style). 
Actively open-minded thinking (AOT) is measured by a short form of actively open-minded thinking scale which is reported to be most relevant to general population (Haran, Ritov, & Mellers, 2013). This scale includes seven items, participants rate to which degree they agree with the statements, ranges from 1 (= Completely Disagree) to 7 (= Completely Agree). Scores on AOT scale is the sum of the ratings after recoding the reversed items.
Participants will be instructed to rate the accuracy of the news headlines through a four-point scale (1 = Not at all accurate, 2 = Not very accurate, 3 = Somewhat accurate, 4 = Very accurate).  
Sharing intention is included as an exploring question. Participants will be asked after each exposure to news headline stimulus if they would share the news on social media(e.g. Facebook or twitter). Intention to share the news: yes = 1, no = 0.

Participants’ score on CRT is the number of correct responses. Scores on AOT scale is the sum of the ratings after recoding the reversed items. Belief in fake news is calculated using the average of all accuracy ratings of all fake news headlines, while belief in real news is represented by the average of accuracy ratings of all real news headlines. Intention to share the news: yes = 1, no = 0.

Outliers in the data will be detected and replaced with winsorized values with assistance of R’s RobustBase package. If the data is normal distributed, outliers will be defined as data points with more than 3 times standard deviation from the sample mean. If the data is skewed, outliers will be identified using the method of Hubert and Van der Veeken (2008).
Correlation. 
Zero-order correlations will be conducted between all variables. Conspiracist ideation is anticipated to be positively related to belief in fake news and negatively related to belief in real news. A negative correlation between conspiracist ideation and analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking is also expected. Both cognitive styles, analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking, are expected to be negatively related to belief in fake news whereas positively related to belief in real news.
Mediation.
Mediation analysis will be conducted to examine whether the relationship between belief in fake news and conspiracist ideation could be partially explained by analytic and actively open-minded thinking. All variables will be standardized before entering mediation analysis. Analytic thinking and AOT will be entered in the same mediation model adopting PROCESS Model 4 (Preacher & Hayes, 2008). The total effect of conspiracist ideation on belief in fake news is expected to be significant. We also expect an indirect effect from conspiracist ideation on belief in fake news through analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking.

q21.value: For Correlations with p-values less than .001 will be reported as significant.

q22.value: Each MTurk ID (unique ID for each user) will be allowed only once to participate in the survey.

q23.value: Uncompleted data will be discarded prior to all data analyses.

q24.value: To explore how sharing intention is related to other variables, we will conduct a Chi-Squared Test with intention to share news headlines as criterion variable.

registration_responses.q1: There is abundant health-related misinformation in internet and misinformation is generally more popular than verified information. While most existing studies focused on political and social issues, health-related misinformation is also highly prevalent on social media. Our research will focus on health-related fake news on social media. We assume that conspiracist ideation positively, analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking negatively, associated with belief in fake news about health.
registration_responses.q3: There is abundant health-related misinformation in internet and misinformation is generally more popular than verified information. While most existing studies focused on political and social issues, health-related misinformation is also highly prevalent on social media. Our research will focus on health-related fake news on social media. We assume that conspiracist ideation positively, analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking negatively, associated with belief in fake news about health.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: Belief in health-related fake news on social media is associated with: (a) a higher conspiracist ideation; (b) less actively open-minded thinking; (c) less analytic thinking.
Hypothesis 2: Analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking simultaneously mediate the association between conspiracist ideation and belief in health-related fake news.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: participants will be assigned with tests in random order, which will be counterbalanced across participants.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q14: Since the preexisting studies showed a small to medium effect size, we calculated an appropriate sample size using G*Power to expect an effect size of 0.20.
registration_responses.q21: For Correlations with p-values less than .001 will be reported as significant.
registration_responses.q22: Each MTurk ID (unique ID for each user) will be allowed only once to participate in the survey.
registration_responses.q23: Uncompleted data will be discarded prior to all data analyses.
registration_responses.q24: To explore how sharing intention is related to other variables, we will conduct a Chi-Squared Test with intention to share news headlines as criterion variable.
registration_responses.q8.question: All participants will complete GCB scale, CRT scale, AOT scale, and complete the 12-item news accuracy judgment task. As CRT requires relatively high working memory resources (Evans & Stanovich, 2013). After each news headline stimulus, participants will be presented with the accuracy judgement question and the sharing intention question. Last part of the survey will be demographic questions including age, gender, education and proficiency in English.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will recruit participants via Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Target group is Mturk workers with good response quality (e.g. an acceptance rate over 95%) who are over 18 and live in the U.S..
registration_responses.q17.question:
Conspiracist ideation is measured by 15-item Generic conspiracist beliefs (GCB) scale which is psychometrically verified and conceptually consistent with the monological construct of conspiracist ideation (Brotherton, French, & Pickering, 2013). Participants are instructed to rate to what extent they think the statements to be true on a 5-point Likert scale (1=definitely not true; 2 = probably not true; 3 = not sure/cannot decide; 4 = probably true; 5 = definitely true). 
Analytical thinking is measured by a reworded version of Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) combining three items from Frederick (2005) and four non-numeric CRT from Thomson and Oppenheimer (2016). The 7-item test was introduced by Pennycook and Rand (2018) with an acceptable reliability proved, Cronbach’s α = 0.77. Participants’ score on CRT is the number of correct responses. Higher scores indicate better cognitive ability and/or more analytic cognitive style (compared to intuitive cognitive style). 
Actively open-minded thinking (AOT) is measured by a short form of actively open-minded thinking scale which is reported to be most relevant to general population (Haran, Ritov, & Mellers, 2013). This scale includes seven items, participants rate to which degree they agree with the statements, ranges from 1 (= Completely Disagree) to 7 (= Completely Agree). Scores on AOT scale is the sum of the ratings after recoding the reversed items.
Participants will be instructed to rate the accuracy of the news headlines through a four-point scale (1 = Not at all accurate, 2 = Not very accurate, 3 = Somewhat accurate, 4 = Very accurate).  
Sharing intention is included as an exploring question. Participants will be asked after each exposure to news headline stimulus if they would share the news on social media(e.g. Facebook or twitter). Intention to share the news: yes = 1, no = 0.
registration_responses.q18.question: Participants’ score on CRT is the number of correct responses. Scores on AOT scale is the sum of the ratings after recoding the reversed items. Belief in fake news is calculated using the average of all accuracy ratings of all fake news headlines, while belief in real news is represented by the average of accuracy ratings of all real news headlines. Intention to share the news: yes = 1, no = 0.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Outliers in the data will be detected and replaced with winsorized values with assistance of R’s RobustBase package. If the data is normal distributed, outliers will be defined as data points with more than 3 times standard deviation from the sample mean. If the data is skewed, outliers will be identified using the method of Hubert and Van der Veeken (2008).
Correlation. 
Zero-order correlations will be conducted between all variables. Conspiracist ideation is anticipated to be positively related to belief in fake news and negatively related to belief in real news. A negative correlation between conspiracist ideation and analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking is also expected. Both cognitive styles, analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking, are expected to be negatively related to belief in fake news whereas positively related to belief in real news.
Mediation.
Mediation analysis will be conducted to examine whether the relationship between belief in fake news and conspiracist ideation could be partially explained by analytic and actively open-minded thinking. All variables will be standardized before entering mediation analysis. Analytic thinking and AOT will be entered in the same mediation model adopting PROCESS Model 4 (Preacher & Hayes, 2008). The total effect of conspiracist ideation on belief in fake news is expected to be significant. We also expect an indirect effect from conspiracist ideation on belief in fake news through analytic thinking and actively open-minded thinking.
